summary: This document is a chain of emails from June 2020 between the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS) and FBI NY CART (Computer Analysis and Response Team) personnel. The emails discuss logistical challenges, staffing issues, and technical plans for transferring and processing terabytes of digital evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's properties in New York and the U.S. Virgin Islands under search warrants. The correspondence reveals significant delays and complexities in handling the evidence for the case. This document is an email chain between U.S. Attorney's Office personnel discussing logistical challenges in managing the massive volume of digital evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's properties. The emails focus on difficulties tracking which devices have been processed, what data has been received, and the need for better organization of the evidence.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The digital evidence being discussed was seized from his residences in New York and the US Virgin Islands (referred to as 'the Island') pursuant to search warrants.

events.title: Coordination for evidence transfer
events.description: Email chain discusses finalizing plans to ship or have hard drives containing Epstein evidence picked up from 'Saint Andrews' to facilitate copying and transfer to the U.S. Attorney's Office.

events.title: Email discussion about Epstein evidence management

Virgin Islands (Epstein's property in the U.S. Virgin Islands)
keyFacts: The FBI NY CART team was processing terabytes of digital evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's properties in New York and the U.S. Virgin Islands under search warrants executed in August and September.

Significant delays in evidence processing and transfer to the U.S. Attorney's Office were caused by staffing issues, the COVID-19 pandemic (reduced office days), and technical challenges in converting forensic data into a reviewable format for the Relativity e-discovery platform.

The seized evidence included a wide variety of devices: phones, tablets, loose media (thumb drives, SD cards), cameras, DVRs, servers, laptops, and desktop computers, some of which required encryption bypass.

Previous data transfers to the U.S. Attorney's Office in early 2020 (over 1.1 million documents) were in an unusable format, lacking links between emails and attachments and proper file attribution to specific devices, necessitating a complete re-transfer of raw data.

The correspondence highlights a methodological conflict: the FBI's forensic, device-by-device review process versus the U.S. Attorney's Office's desire for a bulk, searchable dataset for discovery and taint review purposes.
Evidence seized from Epstein's New York mansion included approximately 40 storage devices (computers, hard drives, thumb drives) and at least 60+ CDs.
Evidence from the Virgin Islands property included more than 25 devices, including multiple servers/server racks.
Prosecutors expressed frustration with the lack of organization in evidence tracking, noting it was 'basically impossible' to keep track of what had been received and processed.
One folder alone ('NYCO24362') contained more than 600,000 items, illustrating the massive scale of digital evidence in the case.
The email chain reveals significant logistical challenges in managing what was described as 'well over a million documents' from the Epstein investigation.
